description: Inherited from Middle English culter, from Old English culter, from Latin culter (“a knife”). For the phonetic development, see poultry.

entries.meaning: A knife or cutter attached to the beam of a plow to cut the sward, in advance of the plowshare and moldboard.
examples: With colters bright the rushy sward bisect, / And in new veins the gushing rills direct  […] .

entries.meaning: The part of a seed drill that makes the furrow for the seed.
